pros: Good work/life balance, salary, benefits. Some amazing people who really care!
cons: SAIT overall can be a good place to work but Employee Services (HR) is horrid and won't change until department leadership changes. Everyone is overworked, and yet they keep reducing numbers. Complaints and concerns go into a void, never to be seen again. Gaslighting is common place, you'll hear a unique answer to the same question from every single person you ask. Most people in the department are just resigned to it and don't care about much, the few good people don't last long, in fact over 50% of the department quit in one go. Do better, SAIT.

review_title: good place to become a power engineer

review_title: Good space for life long learning
pros: Great team, flex days, good vacation, opportunities to learn new roles

pros: Most teaching staff are helpful, supportive and highly skilled; working extra to cover for poor administration (senior management is working to overcome issues of lower and middle management)
cons: Disorganized management, pay can be delayed for months, poor or missing specifications leads to delays and large scope creep (project requirements can easily double, with no increase in payment), lack of knowledge and support from immediate supervisors, project management is the worst I have experienced (simply time-keepers).  These issues can only intensify now that SAIT has greatly increased the number of degree programs offered.

review_title: I like working at SAIT Polytechnic!
pros:
The best reasons to work at SAIT Polytechnic include
1. The faculty and staff are excellent to work with. All (usual exceptions in any org) are focused on student success.
2. It is fun. No day is boring. We are very responsive to industry so are constantly challenged. It is a blast!
3. I came for the opportunity to do productive things for society and to achieve some work/wife balance. I have generally achieved both. 
4. There is opportunity to grow into new areas with support. We have an excellent Credential Enhancement Program that allows/encourages us to further professional development.
5. We have performance bonuses that are achievable. They are driven by collective and individual performance and the criteria are clear.
cons: Workload gets crazy sometimes. It is possible to spend your life here. Work/life balance is the employee's to manage.

pros:
Non union employees get 10 flex days off a year
Time off during Christmas (approx the 25-Jan 6), pending when the stats fall. But still! 
Start off with 4 weeks of vacation
The majority of the benefits kick in almost immediately, with a taxable or healthcare spending account
Free courses!
Great access to food made by the students
Free access to the library, gym and onsite clinic
Free dental work if you are willing to be practiced on by the students
Free swag!
cons:
No bonuses - government funding
No increases - government freeze
Lack of opportunity to move up
Everything takes forever to see any progress
SAIT has a culture of over-consulting
Lots of layers of approvals needed
OT is rarely paid out to salaried non union staff
Conferences and seminars are hard to get approved

pros: Great opportunity to make a difference and to move up in the organization, if you're bright, energetic and collaborative. The salary is quite good and the vacation time for management is excellent. Also,  employees get free access to the gym and pool, library, some free continuing education courses and other perks.  There are a lot of stars, amongst the duds.
cons: It is bureaucratic, slow moving and sometimes stuck on "what we've always done". It can be quite political too. There are a lot of people who don't "get it" and then there are a handful of amazing people. Not many inbetween.

review_title: Counter-productively bureaucratic, stifling of innovation and lack of any succession or career planning
pros: The campus is an amazing location to work within and creates a real sense of community betweens staff and students. The hospitality facilities are great and its fun as an employee to support the students learning experience. The holidays and benefits are certainly competitive within the industry.
cons: The hierarchal and bureaucratic management structure creates an environment of distrust, laziness and lack of innovative thinking. There is no defined career planning structure which inhibits ambitious staff from getting ahead or working towards a future position.

pros: The organization overall is great.  Generally good work life balance, great work schedule, hard working and engaged people in operations, good benefit package and some nice gym and class perks.
cons: Cumbersome and complex processes that are next to impossible to improve because they impact so many people across different groups.  When processes are changed there is invariably a negative impact on several groups because the change is not properly managed.  Some support departments think they run the show rather than acting as the service department that they are.  The revenue model creates certain inefficient behaviours.  Many manual processes that create risk of error.

review_title: They dont practice the values they preach
pros: Good benefits, convenient location and decent perks. There are some great employees that work there and there are a lot of amenities on campus (although not cheap)
cons: Management does not practice the values of open communication, innovation and other things that would truly make SAIT a preferred employer. Communication to subordinates was poor in my area and caused conflict as expectations were not clearly communicated. Performance reviews were non-existent on an ongoing basis.

review_title: Few things are as costly and disruptive as good people walking out the door. ...
pros: as with any instructional/teaching job there is a lot of freedom to work at your own pace, sait has no claim on that. teaching gives you that automatic reward
cons: poor management, poor decision making and done without consulting their best instructional staff, sneaking behind one back to make incompetent decisions and then leave it up to the instructor to clean up the mess and apologize to their student body

pros:
The staff was extremely helpful in providing resources for me to begin instructing classes.
I was very happy with the salary.  I would highly recommend this position to someone considering becoming an instructor at Said.
cons: The contract employees have to join the union.  I don't really know the advantages are.  There isn't free parking for contract instructors.   Sometimes they don't update course materials as quickly as they could.

job_title: Administrative Assistant I in Calgary, AB
pros: Good benefits, good training/educational opportunities, do not need a university degree or even a college degree to get a job.
cons: Low salary relative city average, administrative personnel treated poorly, low morale among non-teaching staff, full 40 hour work week which is uncommon in most other office jobs now, little flexibility for admin staff to adjust their schedules.

pros: There are a lot of different types of learning development videos for online learning and distance learning as well as classroom learning.
cons: The size of SAIT can be overwhelming. The projects may have less planning and time allocated for completion. Just show up and shoot is a common phrase.

review_title: Great benefits, interesting work but at a cost............
pros: Benefits (vacation), working with many different industries (cooking to mechanics), great people, fun students!
cons:
Senior management is not cohesive and often work against each other
Everything is urgent or priority
High workload

review_title: Promotes Managers to their level of incompetence.
pros: There are a lot of interesting amenities on the main campus, and it has a compact layout. There are some great people working there.
cons:
Lack of support for employees, focused instead on micromanagement of high-performing employees instead of on their actual development and progression to maintain that high-performance. 

Tip: Avoid jobs in the Corporate Reporting & Treasury department unless you want to be micromanaged and hindered by management. Other departments in Finance have less turnover and likely have more competent managers. There's a reason there's been at least one person moving out of that area or quitting at least every 6 months (in the little over 2 years I've been in it). And that reason is *bad managers*, since there's less than 10 employees in that area.

I also wasn't pleased when I accepted an internal transfer and the HR person decided to use my existing salary against me as an argument for why I should not negotiate my new salary further. That was highly inappropriate. The two jobs weren't comparable. One was taken as a significant learning opportunity, and the other was a position for which I was far more than qualified and therefore worth more than a simple 10% bump over the previous salary (still well within the salary range for the position).  Another excellent application of SAIT"s FIRST principles.

Also, after giving them substantial notice (several months), they're still planning on taking two weeks to process my final paycheque, not the 3 days allowed as per the Alberta Labour Standards. I can understand this for a small company with a single person payroll department, but they have an entire HR department, with a separate payroll section. 

Incompetence seems to really be the core value here.

pros: this company is dedicated in supporting the people who want to make positive changes in course development and advancement. I have experienced personal and professional mentorship and guidance on my goals
cons: no cons working here. I am very happy with this organization. the position will only be what you make it, positive or negative
